title: Can someone hack your computer through email? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you open the attachment or open the given link(s) then you can be hacked easily hence answer is Yes.But can someone get hacked by just opening email? Answer is Practically No. Let’s analyze all scenarios:- Scenario 1:- Hacker may use email tracking techniques, such as including 1 pixel image (read invisible) in the text, that image is located on hacker’s server. When you open the email, that image is loaded from the hacker’s server and your IP address is recorded. That’s the most hacker can do. Now hacker is left with your IP address. Difficulties in hacking someone by just knowing his IP address are:- Almost every home PC has dynamic IP addresses, hence targeting someone by IP address doesn’t work on most occasions.Even if IP address is static or hacker gets enough time to attack on dynamic IP address. The computer would need to be visible from the Internet (most home PCs aren't, they are behind NAT) .Provided both the above points are in favor of hacker (static IP and no NAT). Then there must have to be a service listening the incoming traffic with either a stupid password, or a vulnerability for which you have an exploit.In nutshell hacking a home PC by using only IP address is highly unlikely to occur. Scenario 2:- There is something else to the story. If you are using a Mail Client (not webmail) then something like this can happen. Many mail programs analyze attachments and generate a thumbnail image. If there is a vulnerability in the library used to generate the thumbnail, you can be attacked through that. This is only theoretical concept, i don’t know if this ever happened or not.Years ago Microsoft Outlook had a vulnerability which allowed emails to run JavaScript code and infect your computer. However, this vulnerability was fixed. Emails cannot use JavaScript. It needs to have great knowledge, sophisticated and specifically targeted attacks to carry out above given hacks. You can conclude that, as long as you are using up-to-date software including your Mail Client, Browser, Browser Plugins, and Operating System. You should be able to open email messages and view them without fear. Thank You…!!!

If a hacker gains access to your email they can cause all kinds of damage to you and others, such as: Get access to your online accountsToday many people use their email address for quick access to Google, YouTube, social media sites like Facebook, online shopping and so on. What’s worse, people often use the same password for many of these, making it even easier for a hacker to access them. But even if they don’t necessarily know the password for these sites, as they already hacked your email and know the password for it, they can simply hit “forgot password” and get it that way. Gain access to your personal informationOnce they have access to your social media sites hackers can also use it to glean your personal information from it. They can, for instance, if you haven’t enabled privacy protections on Facebook find out who your friends are and see your pictures. Steal your financial informationOkay, let’s say you’re not overly concerned about someone seeing your Facebook pictures. What should concern you however is them getting access to your financial information. A lot of us have at some point sent our credit card information over email. In the same manner, a hacker might also use your email to get your online banking information. Once they have those, they might as well have your credit card in their pocket. They can send phishing emailsEven if they don’t have your email password, but only know the address, spammers can still cause damage by using phishing tactics. They might do this in one of two ways. The first is to send you a fake email posing as a legitimate website that looks like it came from a popular service. For instance, you might get an email with a link to a fake PayPal site. Depending on the skills and the effort the scammer put into this, the fake website might look 99% identical to the actual PayPal site. From here, you’ll be prompted to leave credentials and with this in hand, the hackers can gain access to your real PayPal account. They can blackmail youSo maybe stealing your money isn’t enough for the hacker. They might also want to ruin your reputation. Now, you might be thinking “this won’t happen to me” and you might be right. But let’s say you’re a public person, perhaps a politician, and the hacker has something you don’t want publicly known. Well, you’re going to have to pay them to keep their mouth shut.

Lucas will confirm the truth of this story: The easiest way to crack a system using an important password is often ‘People Hacking’ - just ASK someone who has it for the Password. Just one example of many: years ago, I was consulting to a sizeable company. I had visited the Boss Managing Director several times to set things up/give advice etc. I was presenting to all their senior management -including him - in their Boardroom which was glass walled. Said I would show them how easy it could be as long as they promised that no-one would be punished in any way if I did. They agreed. Asking them to wait quietly, I stood up, walked over to stand near the MD and tapped on the glass wall to get the attention of the Bossman’s Secretary sitting at her desk outside his office a few offices away. She looked up, as did half that floor. I waved, smiled and gestured, pointed at my watch etc. then left the room and went to her. Smiling & confident, I explained that the Boss wanted a couple of reports from his PC and had asked that she help me get them (I knew that there was better than 90% chance that she, like most Exec PAs would have had a similar call or request from her Boss before when he was away/at home and would have noted down any necessary details in a handy place - usually in her desk). Sure enough, she slid out a drawer on her desk revealing a sheet with the necessary details scrawled down. You can anticipate the rest as well as the reaction when I went back into the boardroom with the Goodies. Everything was on his PeeCee including confidential memos from his own computer ‘security’ people etc. People are always the weakest link in any ‘Security’. In this case it was The Secretary AND The Bossman himself… But it could have been anybody else.

Yes, absolutely. E-mail is one of the most commonly used techniques for hacking into a computer, or a company’s whole network. This can be via a link or attachment, or by an image (even an image you don’t see, but which contacts a malicious server to retrieve). There are companies which offer “security awareness training” to help explain to companies (and individuals) how to keep their data safe, and to avoid this kind of malicious stuff. One such company (and I have no financial interest in them… I just appreciate what they do) is a company called “knowbe4”. You can Google them. They offer a free security newsletter, which is worth subscribing to. The more you understand the risks, the less likely you are to fall into one of these traps.

Yes you could be hacked through email you receive. An attacker can make a backdoor then crypt it to make it undetectable for an antivirus then bind it with some documents and send it to you through email. Definitely you’ll see whats inside these documents once you open them you are HACKED. Mostly organizations are hacked through their employees emails attacker send all of their emails documents and bind backdoors inside them. There is also a method called email spoofing which an attacker use to forward email from an email that already that specific organize use. So no one can image that they receive a backdoor from their own company email.

One can trace you if you open e-mail sent from such entity. Generally such e-mail contains images whose sources are tied with attacker’s server. Once you open the e-mail, image gets loaded into your mail message and server records your IP from that image. That’s what happens when someone sends you an e-mail using e-mail marketing software like MailChimp etc. Such marketing companies use this simple yet powerful technique to keep records of the e-mail receivers using tiny images. Now if the attacker sends you an e-mail contains such traceable images can reveal your IP. After getting victims IP attacker scans for open ports, vulnerabilities of victims by brute-forcing to your IP and can intrude into your system if the attacker found some useful loopholes. There is no need to even attach an infected attachments to exploit the victim.

Yes, and the older the system, the easier it is to do. All the person has to do is embed a link to an image and have it go back to a server. The server will know you contacted and with what IP. Guess what else happens. The image, which happens to be be a white 1 x 1 pixel image with flawed meta data, might be taking advantage of a gdi subsytem fault which causes a privilege escalation for a java applet that is reaching back to a malware server (because even though it all looks like plain text, it was sent as html.. and most folks DONT configure their systems to convert to plain text)which does a drive by infection with a worm that installs a back door. Bam, ownage.

Yes, someone can hack your system by just one email and one attachment. If you’re on a LAN network, it just gets simpler and easier for the attacker. On the internet, its not impossible, the hack just won’t be permanent(as far as my knowledge base goes). It is possible to exploit vulnerabilities in pdf readers or document viewers to hack into your system using a innocent looking document. I won’t go into much details but if you don’t have a good firewall and antivirus on your system, and don’t keep your software (including application s/w) then with an encrypted package embedded with the file, your system can get compromised.

If the message you receive is just text, I don't know any way it could take over your computer. However, if the message has an attachment (picture, PDF file, Word document, etc.) and you open it, or it has a link and you click it, that could be enough for someone to hack your computer. Also, keep in mind that your first message will give the recipient information about you and your computer equipment. That could provide them information to gather more details about you and your life. Information such as your name, email address, internet service provider, etc.
